entry.subject: Initial Release - version number chosen for consistency with the associated PP-Module

chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.section:
The purpose of a PP-Configuration is to define a Target of Evaluation (TOE) that combines Protection Profiles (PPs) and PP-Modules for various technology types into a single configuration that can be evaluated as a whole. The scope of this PP-Configuration is to define a TOE that consists of a general-purpose software application that also provides email client functionality.
The TOE will be defined by a combination of the components described in section 1.3. Specific instructions on how to ensure consistency between these components is described in section 2.3.

This PP-Configuration is identified as follows:
PP-Configuration for Application Software and Email Client, version 2.1, December 1, 2017
As a shorthand reference, it can be identified as "App+Email PPC 2.1"

This PP-Configuration includes the following components:
Base-PP: Protection Profile for Application Software, Version 1.2 (App PP)
PP-Module: PP-Module for Email Clients, Version 2.1 (Email Client Module)

chapter.title: Conformance Claims
chapter.section:
Conformance Statement
To be conformant to this PP-Configuration, an ST must demonstrate Exact Conformance, a subset of Strict Conformance as defined in [CC] Part 1 (ASE_CCL).
The ST must include all components in the Base-PP that are:
Unconditional (which are always required)
Selection-based (which are required when certain selections are chosen in the unconditional requirements)
and may include components that are
Optional
Objective.
The same conditions apply to the PP-Module that is included as part of this PP-Configuration. Note however that this PP-Module may belong to multiple PP-Configurations and so there are some components that may not be applicable in all cases. Guidance on ensuring that the appropriate claims are made is provided in section 2.3 below.
CC Conformance Claims
This PP-Module is conformant to Parts 2 (extended) and 3 (extended) of Common Criteria Version 3.1, Revision 5 [CC].

In order to evaluate a TOE that claims conformance to this PP-Configuration, the evaluator shall evaluate the TOE against the following SARs that are defined in the Base-PP:
Assurance Class Assurance Components
Security Target (ASE) ST Introduction (ASE_INT.1)
Conformance Claims (ASE_CCL.1)
Security Problem Definition (ASE_SPD.1)
Security Objectives for the Operational Environment (ASE_OBJ.1)
Extended Components Definition (ASE_ECD.1)
Stated Security Requirements (ASE_REQ.1)
TOE Summary Specification (ASE_TSS.1)
Development (ADV) Basic Functional Specification (ADV_FSP.1)
Guidance Documents (AGD) Operational User Guidance (AGD_OPE.1)
Preparative Procedures (AGD_PRE.1)
Life Cycle Support (ALC) Labeling of the TOE (ALC_CMC.1)
TOE CM Coverage (ALC_CMS.1)
Timely Security Updates (ALC_TSU_EXT.1)
Tests (ATE) Independent Testing - Sample (ATE_IND.1)
Vulnerability Assessment (AVA) Vulnerability Survey (AVA_VAN.1)
Note that to fully evaluate the TOE, these SARs shall be applied to the entire TSF and not just the portions described by the Base-PP where the SARs are defined.
In addition to this, both the Base-PP and the PP-Module define "Assurance Activities" for how to evaluate individual SFRs as they relate to the SARs for ASE_TSS.1, AGD_OPE.1, and ATE_IND.1. The Base-PP itself also provides Assurance Activities for the SARs. In evaluating this PP-Configuration, the evaluator shall ensure that all Assurance Activities for SFRs and SARs are evaluated as part of satisfying the required SARs.

Fundamentally, the components included in this PP-Configuration are consistent because their use cases are not contradictory. The App PP defines functional capabilities that any application on a general-purpose computer can be expected to provide. The Email Client Module builds on this by defining functional capabilities that are specific to email clients. These email requirements do not prevent a conformant TOE from implementing all mandatory requirements of the App PP.
The following guidance shall be adhered to for the claims made within the PP-configuration to be consistent.
The ST shall include the mandatory SFRs from each of the PP-Configuration's components:
Section 5.1 of the App PP
Section 5.1 of the Email EP
The ST shall include the following optional and selection-based SFRs from the App PP:
FCS_CKM.1(1)
FCS_CKM_EXT.1
FCS_CKM.2
FCS_COP.1(1)
FCS_COP.1(2)
FCS_COP.1(3)
FCS_COP.1(4)
FCS_TLSC_EXT.1
FIA_X509_EXT.1
FIA_X509_EXT.2
The App PP SFRs shall include the following claims:
FPT_DIT_EXT.1.1 in App PP shall include the selection "encrypt all transmitted sensitive data" and select TLS, at minimum
The ST author shall ensure that all claims made in FCS_CKM and/or FCS_COP are sufficient to address those required by the Email Client Module (for example, if the TOE provides its own hashing function, the claims made in FCS_COP.1(3) shall always include SHA-256 at minimum because it is required by FCS_SMIME_EXT.1.4).
The Email Client Module does not mandate the inclusion or exclusion of any optional or selection-based SFRs to conform to this PP-Configuration.
